conclusion: Determine the initial velocity of the shadow cast by the small ball on the right wall using principles of projectile motion and similar triangles.
Define coordinates and variables: height of light source h, initial position of ball at midpoint between light source and wall, initial velocity of ball v_0, acceleration due to gravity g.
Time to reach maximum height is t_up = v_0/g, total time of flight is T = 2t_up = 2v_0/g.
Height of the ball as a function of time is y(t) = v_0 t - (1/2) g t^2.

Height of the shadow y_shadow can be found using similar triangles: y_shadow/h = d/sqrt((d/2)^2 + (v_0 t - (1/2) g t^2)^2), solving for y_shadow gives y_shadow = h d/sqrt((d/2)^2 + (v_0 t - (1/2) g t^2)^2).
Velocity of the shadow is the derivative of the height of the shadow with respect to time: v_shadow = d y_shadow/d t.
Use properties of similar triangles: ratio of velocities is same as ratio of heights at the same time.
Velocity of the ball is v_b(t) = v_0 - g t, velocity of the shadow is v_s(t) = (2 v_0/sqrt((d/2)^2 + (v_0 t - (1/2) g t^2)^2)) * (v_0 - g t).
Initial velocity of the shadow at t = 0 is v_s(0) = (2 v_0/sqrt((d/2)^2)) * v_0 = (4 v_0^2/d).
The initial velocity of the shadow is v_0/2.
